translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Questions of the Student Dhotaka

analyzed: pucchāmi tam bhagavā brūhi mā ita
translated: “I ask you, Blessed One, please tell me this,
(thus said the venerable Dhotaka)
I desire your words, great seer;
Having heard your voice,
I will train for my own Nibbāna.”
“Therefore, be diligent,
(the Blessed One said to Dhotaka)
Right here, be watchful and mindful;
Having heard from here,
Train for your own Nibbāna.”
“I see in the world of gods and humans,
The contented brahmin who is diligent;
I pay homage to you, all-seeing one,
Release me, Sakka, from doubts.”
“I will not release you, Dhotaka, from doubts,
From any doubts in the world;
Knowing the supreme Dhamma,
Thus you will cross this flood.”
“Instruct me, brahmin, with compassion,
The Dhamma of seclusion that I may know;

analyzed: yathā aham ākāsaḥ uva a byāpajjamānaḥ
translated: So that I, like the sky, may be untroubled,
Right here, being content, I would wander without a home.”
“I will proclaim peace for you,
(the Blessed One said to Dhotaka)
In this very life, without delay,
Knowing what, the mindful one,
Would cross over the flood in the world?”
“I rejoice in that, great seer,
The supreme peace,
Knowing what, the mindful one,
Would cross over the flood in the world?”
“Whatever you understand,
(the Blessed One said to Dhotaka)
Above, below, across, and in the middle;
Knowing this, the world is a hollow reed,
Do not make craving for existence and non-existence.”
The Questions of the Youth Dhotaka is the fifth.
